content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Scholarly works - Computer Science and Technology</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/227506" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle/> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/227506</id> <updated>2015-03-13T00:20:47Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-13T00:20:47Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>HELIX-RC: An Architecture-Compiler Co-Design for Automatic Parallelization of Irregular Programs</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246957" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Campanoni, Simone</name> </author> <author> <name>Brownell, Kevin</name> </author> <author> <name>Kanev, Svilen</name> </author> <author> <name>Jones, Timothy M.</name> </author> <author> <name>Wei, Gu-Yeon</name> </author> <author> <name>Brooks, David</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246957</id> <updated>2015-03-10T15:40:47Z</updated> <published>2014-06-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">HELIX-RC: An Architecture-Compiler Co-Design for Automatic Parallelization of Irregular Programs Campanoni, Simone; Brownell, Kevin; Kanev, Svilen; Jones, Timothy M.; Wei, Gu-Yeon; Brooks, David Data dependences in sequential programs limit parallelization because extracted threads cannot run independently. Although thread-level speculation can avoid the need for precise dependence analysis, communication overheads required to synchronize actual dependences counteract the benefits of parallelization. To address these challenges, we propose a lightweight architectural enhancement co-designed with a parallelizing compiler, which together can decouple communication from thread execution. Simulations of these approaches, applied to a processor with 16 Intel Atom-like cores, show an average of 6.85  performance speedup for six SPEC CINT2000 benchmarks. This is the accepted manuscript. The final version is available from IEEE and ACM at http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?doid=2678373.2665705. </summary> <dc:date>2014-06-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Using Augmented Reality to Elicit Pretend Play for Children with Autism</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246899" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Bai, Zhen</name> </author> <author> <name>Blackwell, Alan F.</name> </author> <author> <name>Coulouris, George</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246899</id> <updated>2015-02-23T09:27:03Z</updated> <published>2015-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Using Augmented Reality to Elicit Pretend Play for Children with Autism Bai, Zhen; Blackwell, Alan F.; Coulouris, George Children with autism spectrum condition (ASC) suffer from deficits or developmental delays in symbolic thinking. In particular, they are often found lacking in pretend play during early childhood. Researchers believe that they encounter difficulty in generating and maintaining mental representation of pretense coupled with the immediate reality. We have developed an interactive system that explores the potential of Augmented Reality (AR) technology to visually conceptualize the representation of pretense within an open-ended play environment. Results from an empirical study involving children with ASC aged 4 to 7 demonstrated a significant improvement of pretend play in terms of frequency, duration and relevance using the AR system in comparison to a non computer-assisted situation. We investigated individual differences, skill transfer, system usability and limitations of the proposed AR system. We discuss design guidelines for future AR systems for children with ASC and other pervasive developmental disorders. This is the accepted manuscript. It is currently under infinite embargo pending publication. </summary> <dc:date>2015-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>A Crime Script Analysis of the Online Stolen Data Market</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246727" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Hutchings, Alice</name> </author> <author> <name>Holt, Thomas J.</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246727</id> <updated>2015-02-11T11:45:50Z</updated> <published>2014-12-09T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">A Crime Script Analysis of the Online Stolen Data Market Hutchings, Alice; Holt, Thomas J. The purpose of this study is to better understand the online black market economy, specifically relating to stolen data, using crime script analysis. Content analysis of 13 English- and Russianspeaking stolen data forums found that the different products and services offered enabled the commodification of stolen data. The marketplace offers a range of complementary products, from the supply of hardware and software to steal data, the sale of the stolen data itself, to the provision of services to turn data into money, such as drops, cashiers and money laundering. The crime script analysis provides some insight into how the actors in these forums interact, and the actions they perform, from setting up software to finalizing transactions and exiting the marketplace. </summary> <dc:date>2014-12-09T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Feature-based Terrain Editing From Complex Sketches</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246704" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Tasse, Flora Ponjou</name> </author> <author> <name>Emilien, Arnaud</name> </author> <author> <name>Cani, Marie-Paule</name> </author> <author> <name>Hahmann, Stefanie</name> </author> <author> <name>Dodgson, Neil</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246704</id> <updated>2015-02-06T11:40:43Z</updated> <published>2014-09-19T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Feature-based Terrain Editing From Complex Sketches Tasse, Flora Ponjou; Emilien, Arnaud; Cani, Marie-Paule; Hahmann, Stefanie; Dodgson, Neil We present a new method for first person sketch-based editing of terrain models. As in usual artistic pictures, the input sketch depicts complex silhouettes with cusps and T-junctions, which typically correspond to non-planar curves in 3D. After analysing depth constraints in the sketch based on perceptual cues, our method best matches the sketched silhouettes with silhouettes or ridges of the input terrain. A deformation algorithm is then applied to the terrain, enabling it to exactly match the sketch from the given perspective view, while insuring that none of the user-defined silhouettes is hidden by another part of the terrain. We extend this sketch-based terrain editing framework to handle a collection of multi-view sketches. As our results show, this method enables users to easily personalize an existing terrain, while preserving its plausibility and style. This is the accepted manuscript. The final version is available from Elsevier at http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0097849314000818 </summary> <dc:date>2014-09-19T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> </feed>
